Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(b).proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(b) and the rules governing district court venue because the Premises and the parties are located in Lynn, Massachusetts, and the wrongful acts alleged occurred in Lynn.

Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] AC 562 (es.raw_text: Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] AC 562 (establishing general duty of care principle).
Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] AC 562 (es.proposition: The risk that a working smoke detector would provide early warning of smoke and fire, reducing the risk of injury from smoke inhalation, is a foreseeable consequence of failing to maintain a smoke detector.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause principles)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: The causal link between Defendant’s breach and Plaintiff’s damages is not broken by any superseding cause; rather, Defendant’s breach was a substantial factor in bringing about Plaintiff’s injuries.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf (Cardozo’s majority) explicitly avoids deciding liability based on proximate cause once it concludes there was no duty to the plaintiff; it therefore does not discuss, let alone affirm, that the defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor or that no superseding cause broke the chain of causation. The opinion states that the “law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us.” Using Palsgraf to show that causation was continuous and substantial is inaccurate and contrary to its reasoning, which turns on duty and foreseeability, not on superseding cause analysis.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us. The question of liability is always anterior to the question of the measure of the consequences that go with liability. If there is no tort to be redressed, there is no occasion to consider what damage might be recovered if there were a finding of a tort.”

MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..raw_text: MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y. 382 (1916) (product of duty principle)
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords have a duty to maintain common areas and to repair dangerous conditions of which they had actual or constructive notice.
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..support_reasoning: The opinion is a New York Court of Appeals products‑liability decision about a manufacturer’s duty to remote purchasers; it does not concern Massachusetts law, landlord‑tenant relationships, common areas, or notice-based duties to repair premises defects. Nothing in the text addresses or recognizes a landlord’s duty to maintain common areas under Massachusetts law. Accordingly, the case does not support the cited proposition.
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was injured in consequence of the collapse of a wheel of an automobile manufactured by the defendant corporation… The present suit is an action for negligence brought by the subvendee of the motor car against the manufacturer as the original vendor… It has heretofore been held in this state that the liability of the vendor of a manufactured article for negligence… is confined to the immediate vendee.”

Alsip v. 275 Newbury Street Condominium.raw_text: Alsip v. 275 Newbury Street Condominium Trust
Alsip v. 275 Newbury Street Condominium.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords have a duty to maintain common areas and to repair dangerous conditions of which they had actual or constructive notice.
